introduction.p:
The previous section introduced vectors and linear combinations and demonstrated how they provide a means of thinking about linear systems geometrically. In particular, we saw that the vector \bvec is a linear combination of the vectors \vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n if the linear system corresponding to the augmented matrix
\left[\begin{array}{rrrr|r} \vvec_1 \amp \vvec_2 \amp \ldots \amp \vvec_n \amp \bvec \end{array}\right]
is consistent.
Our goal in this section is to introduce matrix multiplication, another algebraic operation that connects linear systems and linear combinations.

subsection.title: Matrices
subsection.p:
We first thought of a matrix as a rectangular array of numbers. When the number of rows is m and columns is n, we say that the dimensions of the matrix are m\times n. For instance, the matrix below is a 3\times4 matrix:
\left[ \begin{array}{rrrr} 0 \amp 4 \amp -3 \amp 1 \\ 3 \amp -1 \amp 2 \amp 0 \\ 2 \amp 0 \amp -1 \amp 1 \\ \end{array} \right] .

We may also think of the columns of a matrix as a collection of vectors. For instance, the matrix above may be represented as
\left[ \begin{array}{rrrr} \vvec_1 \amp \vvec_2 \amp \vvec_3 \amp \vvec_4 \end{array} \right]
where
\vvec_1=\left[\begin{array}{r}0\\3\\2\\ \end{array}\right], \vvec_2=\left[\begin{array}{r}4\\-1\\0\\ \end{array}\right], \vvec_3=\left[\begin{array}{r}-3\\2\\-1\\ \end{array}\right], \vvec_4=\left[\begin{array}{r}1\\0\\1\\ \end{array}\right] . In this way, we see that our 3\times 4 matrix is the same as a collection of 4 vectors in \real^3.

subsection.p: As this preview activity shows, both of these operations are relatively straightforward. Some care, however, is required when adding matrices. Since we need the same number of vectors to add and since the vectors must be of the same dimension, two matrices must have the same dimensions as well if we wish to form their sum.

The identity matrix will play an important role at various points in our explorations. It is important to note that it is a square matrix, meaning it has an equal number of rows and columns, so any matrix added to it must be square as well. Though we wrote it as I_n in the activity, we will often just write I when the dimensions are clear.

subsection.title: Matrix-vector multiplication and linear combinations
subsection.p: A more important operation will be matrix multiplication as it allows us to compactly express linear systems. For now, we will work with the product of a matrix and vector, which we illustrate with an example.

statement.p: Let's take note of the dimensions of the matrix and vectors. The two components of the vector \xvec are weights used to form a linear combination of the columns of A. Since \xvec has two components, A must have two columns. In other words, the number of columns of A must equal the dimension of the vector \xvec.
In the same way, the columns of A are 3-dimensional so any linear combination of them is 3-dimensional as well. Therefore, A\xvec will be 3-dimensional.
We then see that if A is a 3\times2 matrix, \xvec must be a 2-dimensional vector and A\xvec will be 3-dimensional.

subsection.p: More generally, we have the following definition.

statement.p: The product of a matrix A by a vector \xvec will be the linear combination of the columns of A using the components of \xvec as weights.

If A is an m\times n matrix, then \xvec must be an n-dimensional vector, and the product A\xvec will be an m-dimensional vector. If
A=\left[\begin{array}{rrrr} \vvec_1 \amp \vvec_2 \amp \ldots \amp \vvec_n \end{array}\right], \xvec = \left[\begin{array}{r} c_1 \\ c_2 \\ \vdots \\ c_n \end{array}\right],
then
A\xvec = c_1\vvec_1 + c_2\vvec_2 + \ldots c_n\vvec_n .

subsection.p: The next activity introduces some properties of matrix multiplication.

subsection.p:
Multiplication of a matrix A and a vector is defined as a linear combination of the columns of A. However, there is a shortcut for computing such a product. Let's look at our previous example and focus on the first row of the product.
\left[\begin{array}{rr} -2 \amp 3 \\ 0 \amp 2 \\ 3 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{r} 2 \\ 3 \\ \end{array}\right] = 2 \left[\begin{array}{r} -2 \\ * \\ * \\ \end{array}\right] + 3 \left[\begin{array}{r} 3 \\ * \\ * \\ \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{c} 2(-2)+3(3) \\ * \\ * \\ \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{r} 5 \\ * \\ * \\ \end{array}\right] .

To find the first component of the product, we consider the first row of the matrix. We then multiply the first entry in that row by the first component of the vector, the second entry by the second component of the vector, and so on, and add the results. In this way, we see that the third component of the product would be obtained from the third row of the matrix by computing 2(3) + 3(1) = 9.
You are encouraged to evaluate using this shortcut and compare the result to what you found while completing the previous activity.

subsection.title: Matrix-vector multiplication and linear systems
subsection.p: So far, we have begun with a matrix A and a vector \xvec and formed their product A\xvec = \bvec. We would now like to turn this around: beginning with a matrix A and a vector \bvec, we will ask if we can find a vector \xvec such that A\xvec = \bvec. This will naturally lead back to linear systems.

To see the connection between the matrix equation A\xvec = \bvec and linear systems, let's write the matrix A in terms of its columns \vvec_i and \xvec in terms of its components.
A = \left[ \begin{array}{rrrr} \vvec_1 \amp \vvec_2 \amp \ldots \vvec_n \end{array} \right], \xvec = \left[ \begin{array}{r} c_1 \\ c_2 \\ \vdots \\ c_n \\ \end{array} \right] .

We know that the matrix product A\xvec forms a linear combination of the columns of A. Therefore, the equation A\xvec = \bvec is merely a compact way of writing the equation for the weights c_i:
c_1\vvec_1 + c_2\vvec_2 + \ldots + c_n\vvec_n = \bvec . We have seen this equation before: Remember that says that the solutions of this equation are the same as the solutions to the linear system whose augmented matrix is
\left[\begin{array}{rrrr|r} \vvec_1 \amp \vvec_2 \amp \ldots \amp \vvec_n \amp \bvec \end{array}\right] .
This gives us three different ways of looking at the same solution space.

statement.p:
If A=\left[\begin{array}{rrrr} \vvec_1\amp\vvec_2\amp\ldots\vvec_n \end{array}\right] and \xvec=\left[ \begin{array}{r} x_1 \\ x_2 \\ \vdots \\ x_n \\ \end{array}\right] , then the following are equivalent.
The vector \xvec satisfies A\xvec = \bvec .
The vector \bvec is a linear combination of the columns of A with weights x_j:
x_1\vvec_1 + x_2\vvec_2 + \ldots + x_n\vvec_n = \bvec .
The components of \xvec form a solution to the linear system corresponding to the augmented matrix
\left[\begin{array}{rrrr|r} \vvec_1 \amp \vvec_2 \amp \ldots \amp \vvec_n \amp \bvec \end{array}\right]\text{.}

subsection.p:
When the matrix A = \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} \vvec_1\amp\vvec_2\amp\ldots\amp\vvec_n\end{array}\right], we will frequently write
\left[\begin{array}{rrrr|r} \vvec_1\amp\vvec_2\amp\ldots\amp\vvec_n\amp\bvec\end{array}\right] = \left[ \begin{array}{r|r} A \amp \bvec \end{array}\right]
and say that we augment the matrix A by the vector \bvec.

We may think of A\xvec = \bvec as merely giving a notationally compact way of writing a linear system. This form of the equation, however, will allow us to focus on important features of the system that determine its solution space.

statement.p:
Describe the solution space of the equation
\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 2 \amp 0 \amp 2 \\ 4 \amp -1 \amp 6 \\ 1 \amp 3 \amp -5 \\ \end{array}\right] \xvec = \left[\begin{array}{r} 0 \\ -5 \\ 15 \end{array}\right]

By , the solution space to this equation is the same as the equation
x_1\left[\begin{array}{r}2\\4\\1\end{array}\right] + x_2\left[\begin{array}{r}0\\-1\\3\end{array}\right]+ x_3\left[\begin{array}{r}2\\6\\-5\end{array}\right]= \left[\begin{array}{r}0\\-5\\15\end{array}\right] , which is the same as the linear system corresponding to
\left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 2 \amp 0 \amp 2 \amp 0 \\ 4 \amp -1 \amp 6 \amp -5 \\ 1 \amp 3 \amp -5 \amp 15 \\ \end{array} \right] .

We will study the solutions to this linear system by finding the reduced row echelon form of the augmented matrix:
\left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 2 \amp 0 \amp 2 \amp 0 \\ 4 \amp -1 \amp 6 \amp -5 \\ 1 \amp 3 \amp -5 \amp 15 \\ \end{array} \right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp -2 \amp 5 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array} \right] . This gives us the system of equations
\begin{alignedat}{4} x_1 \amp \amp \amp {}+{} \amp x_3 \amp {}={} \amp 0 \\ \amp \amp x_2 \amp {}-{} \amp 2x_3 \amp {}={} \amp 5 \\ \end{alignedat} . The variable x_3 is free so we may write the solution space parametrically as
\begin{aligned} x_1 \amp {}={} -x_3 \\ x_2 \amp {}={} 5+2x_3 \\ \end{aligned} .

Since we originally asked to describe the solutions to the equation A\xvec = \bvec, we will express the solution in terms of the vector \xvec:
\xvec =\left[ \begin{array}{r} x_1 \\ x_2 \\ x_3 \end{array} \right] = \left[ \begin{array}{r} -x_3 \\ 5 + 2x_3 \\ x_3 \end{array} \right] =\left[\begin{array}{r}0\\5\\0\end{array}\right] +x_3\left[\begin{array}{r}-1\\2\\1\end{array}\right]
This shows that the solutions \xvec may be written in the form \vvec + x_3\wvec, for appropriate vectors \vvec and \wvec. Geometrically, the solution space is a line in \real^3 through \vvec moving parallel to \wvec.

subsection.title: Matrix products
subsection.p: In this section, we have developed some algebraic operations on matrices with the aim of simplifying our description of linear systems. We will now introduce a final operation, the product of two matrices, that will become important when we study linear transformations in .

Given matrices A and B, we will form their product AB by first writing B in terms of its columns:
B = \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} \vvec_1 \amp \vvec_2 \amp \ldots \amp \vvec_p \end{array}\right] . We then define
AB = \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} A\vvec_1 \amp A\vvec_2 \amp \ldots \amp A\vvec_p \end{array}\right] .

statement.p:
Given the matrices
A = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 4 \amp 2 \\ 0 \amp 1 \\ -3 \amp 4 \\ 2 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right], B = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} -2 \amp 3 \amp 0 \\ 1 \amp 2 \amp -2 \\ \end{array}\right] , we have
AB = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} A \twovec{-2}{1} \amp A \twovec{3}{2} \amp A \twovec{0}{-2} \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} -6 \amp 16 \amp -4 \\ 1 \amp 2 \amp -2 \\ 10 \amp -1 \amp -8 \\ -4 \amp 6 \amp 0 \end{array}\right] .

subsection.p: It is important to note that we can only multiply matrices if the dimensions of the matrices are compatible. More specifically, when constructing the product AB, the matrix A multiplies the columns of B. Therefore, the number of columns of A must equal the number of rows of B. When this condition is met, the number of rows of AB is the number of rows of A, and the number of columns of AB is the number of columns of B.

subsection.p: This activity demonstrated some general properties about products of matrices, which mirror some properties about operations with real numbers.

assemblage.title: Properties of Matrix-matrix Multiplication
assemblage.p:
If A, B, and C are matrices such that the following operations are defined, it follows that
Associativity:
A(BC) = (AB)C.
Distributivity:
A(B+C) = AB+AC.
(A+B)C = AC+BC.

subsection.p: At the same time, there are a few properties that hold for real numbers that do not hold for matrices.

assemblage.title: Things to be careful of
assemblage.p:
The following properties hold for real numbers but not for matrices.
Commutativity:
It is not generally true that AB = BA.
Cancellation:
It is not generally true that AB = AC implies that B = C.
Zero divisors:
It is not generally true that AB = 0 implies that either A=0 or B=0.

subsection.title: Summary
subsection.p:
In this section, we have found an especially simple way to express linear systems using matrix multiplication.
If A is an m\times n matrix and \xvec an n-dimensional vector, then A\xvec is the linear combination of the columns of A using the components of \xvec as weights. The vector A\xvec is m-dimensional.
The solution space to the equation A\xvec = \bvec is the same as the solution space to the linear system corresponding to the augmented matrix \left[ \begin{array}{r|r} A \amp \bvec \end{array}\right].
If A is an m\times n matrix and B is an n\times p matrix, we can form the product AB, which is an m\times p matrix whose columns are the products of A and the columns of B.
